questions.text: Which of the following statements about the isoelectric pH (pI) of a molecule is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: The molecule carries no net charge

options.label: B
options.text: Solubility and buffering capacity will be maximum

options.label: C
options.text: The buffering capacity of plasma proteins are mainly due to Histidine residue.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no mobility in an electric field

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Solubility and buffering capacity will be maximum

Explanation:

  • ➤ The pH at which the molecule carries no net charge is called an isoelectric point or isoelectric pH (pI). At an isoelectric point , the amino acid will carry no net charge, all the groups are ionized but the charges will cancel each other. Hence, at isoelectric point, there is no mobility in an electrical field. Solubility and buffering capacity will be minimum at isoelectric pH. The buffering capacity of plasma proteins and hemoglobin is mainly due to histidine residue.

  • ➤ Some Properties of Chaperone Proteins:
  • ➤ Some Properties of Chaperone Proteins:
  • ➤ Present in a wide range of species from bacteria to humans Many are heat shock proteins (Hsp) and are known as stress proteins. Some are inducible by conditions which cause unfolding of newly synthesized proteins (e.g. elevated temperature and various chemicals). They bind to predominantly hydrophobic regions of unfolded proteins thus preventing their aggregation. They act as a quality control or editing mechanism for detecting misfolded or defective proteins. Most chaperones have associated ATPase activity, with ATP or ADP being involved in the protein-chaperone interaction. questions.text: A 3.5-year-old girl of Arabian descent presents to the clinic with severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis, and elevated ESR. The history provided by her parents includes fever, cough, pallor, weakness, and tachypnea. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. Following diagnostic evaluations, sickle cell anemia (SCA) is diagnosed. Based on the information provided, which of the following statements about SCA is false?

options.label: A
options.text: RFLP result from a single base change

options.label: B
options.text: Single nucleotide change results in change of Glutamate to Valine

options.label: C
options.text: HbS confers resistance against malaria in heterozygotes

options.label: D
options.text: ‘Sticky patch’ is generated as a result of replacement of a nonpolar residue with a polar residue in Sickle Cell Anemia (HbS)

questions.correct_answer: D. ‘Sticky patch’ is generated as a result of replacement of a nonpolar residue with a polar residue in Sickle Cell Anemia (HbS)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) ‘Sticky patch’ is generated as a result of replacement of a nonpolar residue with a polar residue in Sickle Cell Anemia (HbS) — this is False.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In sickle cell anemia , the amino acid substitution involves replacing a polar residue Glutamate with a nonpolar residue (valine) at the 6th position of the β-globin chain.
  • • sickle cell anemia
  • • polar residue Glutamate
  • • nonpolar residue (valine)
  • • This substitution creates a hydrophobic “sticky patch” on the surface of the deoxygenated hemoglobin S (HbS) molecule. These hydrophobic patches interact abnormally with each other, leading to polymerization of HbS inside red cells, which causes the characteristic "sickling" shape of RBCs under hypoxic conditions.
  • • hydrophobic “sticky patch”
  • • polymerization of HbS
  • • So the false statement is that the “sticky patch” arises from a nonpolar → polar substitution — the reality is the opposite: → It’s a polar (glutamate) → nonpolar (valine) substitution.
  • • nonpolar → polar substitution
  • • polar (glutamate) → nonpolar (valine)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) RFLP result from a single base change: Correct — The sickle cell mutation involves a single nucleotide change ( A → T at the 6th codon), which eliminates a restriction enzyme site. This difference can be detected using Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) analysis. Option B) Single nucleotide change results in change of Glutamate to Valine: Correction: this statement is Correct . Option C) HbS confers resistance against malaria in heterozygotes: Correct — Heterozygotes for the HbS gene (sickle cell trait) are relatively protected against Plasmodium falciparum malaria , explaining its evolutionary persistence in malaria-endemic regions.
  • • Option A) RFLP result from a single base change: Correct — The sickle cell mutation involves a single nucleotide change ( A → T at the 6th codon), which eliminates a restriction enzyme site. This difference can be detected using Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) analysis.
  • • Option A) RFLP result from a single base change:
  • • A → T
  • • Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP)
  • • Option B) Single nucleotide change results in change of Glutamate to Valine: Correction: this statement is Correct .
  • • Option B) Single nucleotide change results in change of Glutamate to Valine:
  • • Correction:
  • • Correct
  • • Option C) HbS confers resistance against malaria in heterozygotes: Correct — Heterozygotes for the HbS gene (sickle cell trait) are relatively protected against Plasmodium falciparum malaria , explaining its evolutionary persistence in malaria-endemic regions.
  • • Option C) HbS confers resistance against malaria in heterozygotes:
  • • Plasmodium falciparum malaria

Educational Objective:

This creates a hydrophobic site ("sticky patch") on deoxygenated HbS, triggering polymerization, red cell sickling, hemolysis, and vaso-occlusive complications.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the interaction of hemoglobin with 2, 3-BPG

questions.correct_answer: B. Binding of 2,3 BPG decreases the affinity of Hb to O2 and shifts the ODC to right
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: 2, 3-BPG is an intermediate of gluconeogenesis: This statement is incorrect. 2, 3-BPG is formed from 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate during glycolysis, not gluconeogenesis.

  • • Option C: Binding of 2,3-BPG stabilizes the R state: This is incorrect. 2, 3-BPG binds to and stabilizes the T (tense) state of Hb , not the R (relaxed) state , which has a higher affinity for oxygen.
  • • Option C: Binding of 2,3-BPG stabilizes the R state:
  • • incorrect.
  • • 2, 3-BPG
  • • T (tense) state of Hb
  • • not
  • • R (relaxed) state
  • • higher affinity for oxygen.
  • • Option D: 2, 3-BPG has increased interaction with HbF: This is incorrect . HbF has a lower affinity for 2, 3-BPG than adult hemoglobin (HbA), which contributes to its higher affinity for oxygen , facilitating oxygen transfer from the mother to the fetus.

  • • 2, 3-BPG has increased interaction with HbF:
  • • incorrect

  • • adult hemoglobin
  • • its higher affinity for oxygen
  • • facilitating oxygen
  • • mother to the fetus.

questions.text: Assertion (A): In well-fed state, activity of acetyl CoA carboxylase activity is increased. Reasoning (R): Citrate produced from acetyl CoA in well-fed state acts as an allosteric activator of acetyl CoA carboxylase:

options.label: A
options.text: A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A

options.label: B
options.text: A is wrong but R is a right statement

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: A and R both are wrong

questions.correct_answer: C. A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acetyl CoA carboxylase is an enzyme crucial in fatty acid synthesis. In a well-fed state, the abundance of acetyl CoA leads to the production of citrate , which can be transported out of the mitochondria into the cytosol .

questions.text: A research team studying metabolic responses to nutrient deprivation measures enzymatic activities in subjects after a 24-hour fast. They aim to determine which enzyme associated with lipid metabolism shows decreased activity in this energy-conserving state. Which enzyme is the research team least likely to find elevated in the fasting state?

questions.text: Sources of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis include all the following reactions, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase : This enzyme is the first in the pentose phosphate pathway and is a major source of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis by oxidizing glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphogluconolactone.

  • • first in the pentose phosphate pathway
  • • major source
  • • NADPH for fatty acid synthesis

  • • Option B: 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase : Also part of the pentose phosphate pathway, this enzyme further contributes to NADPH production by oxidizing 6-phosphogluconate to ribulose-5-phosphate.
  • • Option B: 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase
  • • pentose phosphate pathway,
  • • NADPH production
  • • 6-phosphogluconate to ribulose-5-phosphate.
  • • Option D: Malic enzyme : This enzyme catalyzes the decarboxylation of malate to pyruvate, producing NADPH in the process, and serves as an additional source of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis.

  • • NADPH
